results.title: For a lost soldier = Voor een verloren soldaat
results.creator_credit: Roeland Kerbosch, Matthijs van Heijningen and Sigma Film Productions
results.brief_description: Forty years after the fact, choreographer Jeroen Boman (Jeroen Krabbe), recalls his childhood experiences as an adolescent in wartime Holland. Evacuated from Amsterdam to a country village, young Jeroen (Maarten Smit) is troubled by the isolation from his family and the sexual curiosity of the girls and boys around him. Once the Allied Forces move into the village, Jeroen enters into a tender relationship with Canadian soldier, Walt (Andrew Kelley). Never stooping to sensationalism, this gay ‘coming of age’ film is delicately handled and beautifully written. From the novel by Rudi Van Dantzig. In Dutch with English subtitles.

results.title: Zero patience
results.creator_credit: John Greyson, Anna Stratton, Louise Garfield and Zero Patience Productions
results.brief_description: John Greyson’s Zero Patience takes as its premise, the very serious subject of the history and politics of the AIDS virus and turns it into an offbeat hybrid of the Hollywood musical. Referencing and connecting unlikely subjects like French philosopher Michel Foucault, Busby Berkeley musicals and the history of contagious diseases. The films playful lack of respect for historical figures and its fairly decent musical numbers are some of its many pleasures. (Not to mention singing sphincters and a drag queen HIV virus!) Set in present day Toronto, Zero Patience has famous sexologist and explorer Sir Richard Francis Burton (John Robinson), still alive due to his discovery of the fountain of youth and working as chief taxidermist for the Natural History Museum. His current project, a retrospective of famous diseases of the ages. Enter patient zero (Normand Fauteux), the ghost of the Canadian flight attendant believed to be the first reported AIDS fatality, who has come back from the dead to clear his name and set the record straight.

results.title: Grief
results.creator_credit: Richard Glatzer, Ruth Charny, Yoram Mandel and Grief Productions
results.brief_description: This comic melodrama follows a group of maladjusted scriptwriters who work together on ‘The Love Judge’, a trashy daytime TV show set in a California divorce court. Mark is still grieving for his lover Kenny, but he’s in with a chance for a production job and is besotted with Bill who’s just broken up with his girlfriend. Leslie prefers Ben, the photocopier repair man while the boss Jo is preoccupied with the mysterious stains on her office couch. Fully of campily enjoyable scenes, the film is also genuinely touching. Glatzer delineates a complex set of relationships with assurance in this well structured, carefully nuanced film.

results.title: Fiesta
results.creator_credit: Pierre Bouton, Jean-Marie Richard, GIPA Productions and HECK Productions
results.brief_description: A young aristocratic military cadet gets a dose of reality when he is called to fight in the Spanish Civil War in this French anti-war drama. It is 1936 and Rafael is the sixteen year old son of a senior officer in the pro-Franco ranks. His father decides that his son, heir to a family traditionally dedicated to the army, must “do his duty.” Before going to the front, Rafael is placed under the command of Colonel Massagual, a cynical and derisive character who has made a profession of war. Massagual takes charge of Rafael’s military training, while Celia, a beautiful English nurse, concentrates on his sentimental education. In French with English subtitles. Cast includes Jean-Louis Trintignant, Gregoire Colin, Marc Lavoine and Jean-Philip Ecoffey.

results.title: Walkabout
results.creator_credit: Nicolas Roeg, Si Litvinoff and Max L. Raab - Si Litvinoff Films
results.brief_description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister and her young brother left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They’re rescued by a young Aboriginal man (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicolas Roeg, Si Litvinoff and Max L. Raab - Si Litvinoff Films
results.description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister (Jenny Agutter) and her young brother (Lucien John) left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They are rescued by a young First Nations man (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood. During their journey Gulpilil courts the young woman, though in her incomprehension she rejects his advances. The vision of paradise lost presented with an often surreal intensity is that of a European outsider, who sees white history as invasive and deeply destructive. Also stars John Meillon, Robert McDara, Pete Carver, John Illingsworth, Hilary Bamberger, Barry Donnelly, Noelene Brown and Carlo Machini. Cinematography by Nicolas Roeg. Screenplay by Edward Bond, based on the novel by James Vance Marshall. Edited by Antony Gibbs and Alan Pattillo. Music composed and conducted by John Barry. Also available on DVD [319241]

results.title: Wages of fear = Salaire de peur
results.creator_credit: Louis Wipf, Raymond Borderie, Henri-Georges Clouzot, CICC, Filmsonor (Paris), Fono Roma and Vera Films
results.brief_description: This film runs along the traditional template of any story - a beginning, which unhurriedly and deliberately sets the scene, a middle section that carries the plotline, and a brief ending that resolves everything to no one’s satisfaction. The beginning paints a picture of a world unimaginable to anyone from a developed country, of corruption, poverty, and oppression. It simultaneously describes the main characters - a bunch of immigrants who have strayed to this miserable little town, and for whom there is little chance of escape from the baking heat and unemployment. There is Mario, the happy-go-lucky scrounger, Luigi, his hard-working Italian pal, the comically tyranical tavern owner, his much abused maid, and Jo, the suave and dangerous French gangster. Homosexuality, racism, and the oppression of women figure prominently, but are never commented upon directly, as various prison motifs are evident in the lighting and set construction. Suddenly there is a change - a way out for a ‘lucky’ four of the deadbeats. There has been an explosion at an oil well on the other side of the mountain. The oil company needs to put out the fire with explosives, which are stored in the town. But its nitro-glycerine, and there is no time to get specially-fitted trucks to carry it over the rough mountains roads. Rather than risk their own employees, the oil company offers a large reward to four volunteers. Cue the action as first the men compete for the places on the two trucks, then as the winners embark on their terrifying journey, where every bump could spell instant death. On the journey their true characters emerge. One, Jo, is broken by the ordeal, but is eventually redeemed. ‘How exciting could a simple road trip be?’ you might ask, but the one and a half hour screen journey is petrifyingly spellbinding. Fate seems to be stacked against these bedraggled heroes, but it is their ingenuity, effort and bravery which captures our hearts. In French and Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Rock Hudson's home movies
results.brief_description: This documentary takes the film-clip biography to new heights. Narrated by ‘Rock’ it wittily dissects the late star’s screen career in the light of the now known facts of his life— that he was gay and died from AIDS. The film presents a new image of Hollywood’s leading romantic screen idol of the 50s and 60s by closely examining his screen roles for ‘hidden meanings’ Both poignant and funny it exposes the ‘queerness’ the sits just below the surface of mainstream Hollywood film.

results.title: Wonderful world of the Brothers Grimm
results.creator_credit: Henry Levin, George Pal, Cinerama, Gallen Films and Turner Entertainment
results.brief_description: Brothers Wilhelm and Jacob Grimm (Laurence Harvey and Karl Boehm) are commissioned to write a family history for a local Duke; the setting, the nineteenth century. The task seems doomed as Wilhelm is far more content creating stories about fairies, elves, knights and princesses to include in a collection of folktales. Jacob reluctantly agrees to help his brother, provided it doesn’t interfere with the serious task at hand. This fictionalised account of two of the world’s greatest story tellers is interspersed with adaptations of some of their stories. An international cast brings to life some of the Brothers Grimms’ best loved fairy tales including “The Dancing Princess”, “The Cobbler and the elves” and “The Singing bone”. The cast of these fairy tales includes Claire Bloom, Karl Boehm, Walter Slezak, Oscar Homolka, Barbara Eden, Yvette Mimieux, Jim Backus and Beulah Bondi. A delightful account that will be enjoyed by viewers of all ages.

results.title: Gabbeh
results.creator_credit: Mohsen Makhmalbaf, Khalil Daroudchi, Khalil Mahmoudi, MK2 Productions and Sanayeh Dasti
results.brief_description: With “Gabbeh” Mohsen Makhmalbaf creates a romantic parable of universal resonance. A gabbeh is an Iranian carpet produced by the nomadic Ghashghai tribe of southern Iran. This episodic tale is framed with exquisite interludes on the colours of nature, painting each scene with landscapes and vistas of breathtaking beauty.

results.title: Donnie Brasco
results.creator_credit: Mike Newell, Barry Levinson, Gail Mutrux, Louis Digiamo, Mark Johnson and Mandalay Entertainment
results.brief_description: This is a gangster movie quite like no other which is more concerned with character study, friendship and betrayal. Donnie Brasco (Johnny Depp), also known as Joe the Jeweller, befriends Mafia small man and former assassin Lefty Ruggiero (Al Pacino). Lefty sees in the young Donnie a chance to rise in the Mafia ranks, something the aging Lefty, with his drug addicted son and passive wife is no longer capable of. Unbeknown to Lefty, Donnie Brasco is an under cover special agent, working with the FBI to infiltrate the New York Mafia underworld. What at first seems a simple case of undercover work is complicated by Donnie’s genuine feelings of friendship towards Lefty and Lefty’s loyalty towards Donnie. Based on the book by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. Also starring Michael Madsen, Bruno Kirby, James Russo and Anne Heche.
